claim: The Lindbergh kidnapping case was solved, although alternative theories still exist.

supporting.text: Bruno Hauptmann was convicted and executed for the Lindbergh kidnapping, providing a clear resolution to the case.

attacks.text: Bruno Hauptmann was convicted and executed for the Lindbergh kidnapping, providing a clear resolution to the case.
Hauptmann maintained his innocence until his execution, casting doubt on the fairness of his trial.
Some forensic evidence used in the trial has been questioned by modern experts.
Despite his claims of innocence, the jury found Hauptmann guilty based on substantial evidence presented during the trial.
Modern forensic techniques were not available at the time, but the evidence was considered reliable by contemporary standards.
Eyewitness testimony and circumstantial evidence strongly supported Hauptmann's guilt.

supporting.text: Forensic evidence, including the ladder used in the kidnapping, was linked to Hauptmann, strongly supporting his guilt.

attacks.text: Forensic evidence, including the ladder used in the kidnapping, was linked to Hauptmann, strongly supporting his guilt.
The ladder's wood could have been contaminated or mishandled, casting doubt on the forensic link to Hauptmann.
Hauptmann had an alibi for the night of the kidnapping, which was not thoroughly investigated.
Chain of custody records for the ladder were incomplete, raising questions about evidence integrity.
Witnesses supporting Hauptmann's alibi were dismissed without proper scrutiny, suggesting bias in the investigation.
Standard forensic protocols for evidence handling were followed, as documented by independent experts.
The alibi witnesses had inconsistencies in their testimonies, justifying their dismissal.

supporting.text: Hauptmann was found in possession of ransom money, which was traced back to the Lindbergh family, further implicating him.

attacks.text: Hauptmann was found in possession of ransom money, which was traced back to the Lindbergh family, further implicating him.
The chain of custody for the ransom money was poorly documented, raising doubts about its authenticity as evidence.
Hauptmann claimed the money was given to him by a friend who later died, making it impossible to verify his story.
Forensic accounting techniques at the time were not advanced enough to conclusively link the money to the Lindbergh family.
The friend's death was never properly investigated, leaving open the possibility that Hauptmann's story was true.
Modern forensic methods have since validated the original tracing of the ransom money, supporting its authenticity.

supporting.text: Alternative theories lack substantial evidence compared to the overwhelming case against Hauptmann.

attacks.text: Alternative theories lack substantial evidence compared to the overwhelming case against Hauptmann.
Some alternative theories present credible witness testimonies that contradict the official narrative.
Forensic techniques used in the Hauptmann case were primitive by modern standards, casting doubt on the evidence.
The witness testimonies in alternative theories have been debunked as unreliable or fabricated.
Modern forensic re-examinations have confirmed the validity of the original evidence against Hauptmann.

supporting.text: Some historians argue that Hauptmann may have been part of a larger conspiracy, casting doubt on the completeness of the official solution.

attacks.text: Some historians argue that Hauptmann may have been part of a larger conspiracy, casting doubt on the completeness of the official solution.
The evidence against Hauptmann was overwhelming, including the ransom money found in his possession and his handwriting matching the ransom notes.
No credible evidence has emerged to support the existence of a larger conspiracy beyond Hauptmann's involvement.
Forensic analysis at the time confirmed that the ladder used in the kidnapping was constructed with wood from Hauptmann's attic.
Multiple witnesses placed Hauptmann near the crime scene around the time of the kidnapping.
Investigations into potential co-conspirators yielded no substantial leads or evidence.

supporting.text: The investigation was marred by mishandling of evidence and media sensationalism, raising questions about the validity of the conviction.

attacks.text: The investigation was marred by mishandling of evidence and media sensationalism, raising questions about the validity of the conviction.
Despite the mishandling, forensic evidence like the ladder and ransom notes directly linked Bruno Hauptmann to the crime.
The jury was convinced beyond a reasonable doubt by the totality of the evidence, including Hauptmann's possession of the ransom money.
The forensic methods used at the time were rudimentary and could have led to contamination or misinterpretation of evidence.
Eyewitness testimony and circumstantial evidence are often unreliable, which could have influenced the jury's decision.
Modern forensic re-examinations have confirmed the validity of key evidence, such as wood grain matching on the ladder.
